title: JPMorganâ€™s Surprise Dealmaking Gain Shows Tariff Fear Easing | Bloomberg Intelligence

rawLines.text: Bloomberg Audio Studios, podcasts,
radio, news.
You're listening to the Bloomberg
Intelligence Podcast. Catch us live
weekdays at 10 a.m. Eastern
on Apple CarPlay and Android Auto with
the Bloomberg Business App. Listen on
demand wherever you get your podcasts or
watch us live on YouTube. Welcome back,
Bloomberg Intelligence. I'm Lisa Matteo
alongside Paul Sweeney. Big day for bank
earnings. Some mixed reports though.
Taking a look at the stock. We have JP
Morgan. They're down their shares down
about half percent. Wells Fargo down 5%.
We have City up about 1 and a.5%. So
here to break it all down for us and
what happened with each bank is Allison
Williams. Who else? Bloomberg
Intelligence senior analyst global banks
and asset managers. Allison, thanks for
joining us here in the studio. Good to
see you. Um, so let's start with JP
Morgan, right? They had some surprise
deal making gains. I mean, is that a
sign that tariff fears are easing or how
do you take it?
Yeah, I mean, they had a solid quarter.
There's always a high bar for for JP
Morgan, but I think a really good
quarter, strong returns, uh, good
organic growth, and I think, you know,
about a billion dollars of upside with
trading and fees. And so, I think that
we, you know, we did see that that fee
pick up. We saw April stall, then we saw
fees really did pick up in in May and
June. As you said, it really is the the
advisory business was big upside um you
know for both JP Morgan and city and um
we also saw IPOs better and so we have
seen that improving sentiment. I think
there is going to be a little bit of a
lift in terms of some of the
expectations for those banking fees
going forward as well.
Red headline crossing the Bloomberg
terminal. Tesla's top North America
sales executive Troy Jones exits. That's
according to the Wall Street Journal. So
when it rains, it pours there. All
right, here we go. So we had JP Morgan,
Cityroup, and Wells Report today. Guess
what? I worked at all of those firms.
Chase Manhattan Bank, now part of now
part of JP Morgan. Solomon Brothers, now
part of Cityroup. And Wheat First
Securities, which is now part of Wells
Fargo. That's where Wells Fargo got its
original broker dealer license by
acquiring my firm, Weat Securities,
Richmond, Virginia. So I got I'm biased
all over the place here. Let's start
with Sig Group. I think that's got the
most upside cuz I think it's
underperformed for such a long time it
was just begging for really really
really good management. Is this I mean
the stock's hitting 52- week high today.
Is this the turnaround that everybody's
been waiting for? Do you think?
I think yeah Jane is getting it done
right. So, um, and and and to be fair,
you know, her predecessors made some
changes, but I think she's she's made
some tough decisions, you know,
especially the the sale of the, you
know, the Mexico business where uh she
really uh cut her teeth. I think that is
a a sign that she can be objective in
terms of deciding what's right for the
business and they are working their way
up um to some better returns. So, you
know, we there's a lot of talk about the
evaluation for Cityroup. We know that
they trade at a discount to their book
value. They trade at a discount to their
peers.
Wow.
That's what happens when you don't um
earn your cost of capital and your
returns are below peers. Y
um but I think the changes that they're
making are moving them in the right
direction. So when I look at Wells Fargo
because I'm trying to go through the the
information. Um so the big thing that
kind of stands out to me is that it
crossed the 1.95 trillion asset mark. Is
that a big milestone?
Well, the removal of the asset cap that
is really I think that the big
structural benefit and I think that goes
to the number that you're talking about
where you know for years they had to
limit their balance sheet growth. They
finally got the go-ahad that you know we
don't have to be so concerned about what
that exact number is. I think the stock
has really um priced in a lot of the
optimism around uh getting that asset
cap removed. I mean basically has been
um you know a huge gainer since the US
election. I think the shares are
responding today to the lower net
interest income outlook. And I think
there's a couple things there. The the
core net interest income that's what
people focus on, right? because the the
income that you get from trading
generally has an offset to fees and but
if you're just focusing on top on you're
just focusing on that number people are
disappointed in that outlook for Wells
Fargo. What are you hearing from these
banks uh today and and over the coming
days about loan growth because it seems
like with the you know yield curve
steepening um it's a good time to be
making loans. How's the demand out there
because all they hear about is private
credit here, private credit there. How
about the banks? I mean we are we did
see like things a little bit better. I
would say that you know the the own grow
loan growth is is still a bit modest but
the expectation in terms of reduced risk
to the economy is really a positive for
these banks going into uh the second
half. And so I think there's there's
certainly room for improvement in the
loan growth but I think things were
fine.
Well there's been the the loosening of
regulations capital requirements for the
banks. I mean, did this show up in the
results or or or when will it?
I think that's that is something that is
going to come over time. I mean, we did
see some some some good buybacks um at
Wells Fargo, for example, but I think
the big news was the stress tests that
we saw in June basically are signaling
that their capital hurdles are going
lower. um further a proposal out there
that um you know there we're going to
have sort of average results over time.
So that for this year means that the the
you know the decreases might not be as
much and they might come a little bit
later but we think that's positive over
time because what that means is that
there'll be more stabilization and not
sort of these ratios moving around a
lot. So, lots of excess capital at the
banks, even more as those ratios go
lower. That means uh more buybacks,
especially since we expect that any
further regulations are not going to be
as drastic.
Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, they
report tomorrow. I always love looking
at, you know, the way you guys analyze
kind of league tables and how people are
doing competitively. What do you expect
to hear from those two investment banks?
I mean, so we expect strength. I mean
this the the the results that we saw
today in terms of uh fixed income
trading better than expected equities
trading better than expected fees almost
across the board better than expected.
We talked about the IPOs like that's a
really good sign for uh Morgan Stanley
and Goldman the M&A you know uh Goldman
is typically an M&A leader there
although JP Morgan has really been
catching up. So those are all very
positive signals. I mean, 27% growth
year-over-year in uh Cityroup's rates
and currencies business. That is a
really strong result. And, you know,
Goldman and Morgan Stanley lead in the
equities. They earn the most from these
businesses. So, I think that, you know,
the bar is definitely higher for them
tomorrow.
All right. Good stuff. We appreciate it.
Allison Williams, senior analyst, Global
Banks, Asset Managers, Bloomberg
Intelligence. She's been doing it for a
long time. She worked on the buy side at
Morgan Stanley Investment Management,
investing in uh these big banks. So, she
knows what she's doing. She's got a
great team uh there at Bloomberg
Intelligence on a global basis looking
at some of the big global uh banks
around the world. So, I appreciate
getting a couple minutes of her time.
You're listening to the Bloomberg
Intelligence Podcast. Catch us live
weekdays at 10 a.m. Eastern
on Apple CarPlay and Android Auto with
the Bloomberg Business App.
Listen on demand wherever you get your
podcasts or watch us live on YouTube.
want to turn our attention to healthcare
company uh managed care company United
Health Group. It's a big company, $267
billion, uh in market cap. It's down 40%
year to date, but it's had a distinction
of having, I think, 60 consecutive
quarters that kind of beat earnings
estimates out there. But I think
analysts are starting to take another
look at some of those earnings numbers
and taking a look at how this company
put those numbers up. And I remember
this kind of story back in the day from
General Electric where they would just
beat by a couple of pennies every single
quarter. Uh but that turned out to be a
little bit of a mirage when you go back
and look at some of the the data there.
Uh Michelle Davis joins us here,
Bloomberg senior deals reporter.
Michelle, what'd you find when you're
looking at United Healthcare? How are
they making some of those numbers
recently?
So yeah, as you mentioned, they had kind
of a pristine record for more than 60
quarters. They beat estimates. Analysts
love them. And at the end of last year,
that got a bit harder for them to keep
up. You know, medical costs were rising.
The government's been cracking down on
on reimbursements, and that was eating
into profits. And so, what we reported
is that at the end of last year, they
approached se several private equity
firms and asked them if they wanted to
buy stakes off of them of their
businesses. And a couple interesting
things happened here. Not only did they
quietly do this, but the deals were
structured such that United Health can
be forced to buy the businesses back
down the road. So, it's temporary in
nature. And um United booked the gains
in an interesting place. They booked
them as part of operating earnings,
which is or adjusted earnings, which is
normally where you look to see kind of
how a business is doing, you know,
excluding one-off gains or one-off
events like this. And so it was just
interesting to see not only the fact
that they stealthily did this but where
they put them and and without these
gains they would have missed estimates
and profit would have dropped uh in the
last quarter of last year. So as I'm
going through this article this this
certain quote stands out for me from an
analyst that you spoke to. He said if
the company is manufacturing earnings by
chopping up their furniture or selling
their assets that's not exactly a great
business model. Okay. So, is the risk
that it might be kind of masking this
weakness in the operations?
That's the concern. And just to be
clear, you know, there's nothing illegal
about what they're doing per se. You
know, they disclosed that they did this.
Most people didn't see it. It was in a
footnote in their 10K that kind of went
under the radar. There are no details
about what exactly they sold. That's
what we're trying to, you know, report
on here. But yeah, the the concern is it
clouds, you know, your ability to see
how the business is actually performing.
and and we heard from sources that
there's a culture inside United Health
of, you know, kind of there being this
pressure to do whatever you can to meet
targets every quarter.
Yep. Um so again, the stock, it's a huge
company, huge player in the managed care
business, but stock's down 40%. What's
the underlying concern for investors out
there, do you think, around this
company?
United Health has been dealing with a
lot of things. I mean, even before we
knew about this, uh there was obviously
the the tragedy of, you know, one of
their executives being um murdered last
year and then, you know, there was a
Wall Street Journal investigation this
year about potential Medicare fraud,
which they have denied. They also in the
first quarter reported their first
earnings miss in, you know, more than 60
quarters. So, that shoe finally dropped.
They ousted their CEO. So, investors are
just concerned about the story here. You
know, what what is the United Health
story? I think that's what the big
concern is.
So, are there any other companies like
maybe other health companies or or or
something like that where this same
story that you've been talking about
kind of plays out?
Not that we could find. It seems like
United Health is really, you know,
unique in its um ability and and history
of, you know, really carefully managing
um its reporting every quarter.
So, new management team here. What's
kind of the focus now of the company?
What's kind of the message to Wall
Street about how they're I guess going
to try to turn this thing around?
So, they brought in their former CEO who
is a accountant by by nature and it
seems like the market's pretty uh
they've been put at ease by him. The
view or the hope from analysts is that
the last quarter was kind of an anomaly
and they were just bleeding out all the
bad stuff and now they'll have a lower
base to kind of beat off of. They report
earnings later this month. So, so we'll
see, you know, how the business is
actually doing. The big surprise in the
first quarter was that um you know
medical costs were a lot higher than
than they say they they anticipated.
That was confusing to people because
their job is to anticipate that. But
that's what I when we when we're
reporting on that story a couple weeks
ago I said isn't that the job of the
company to know how that's going to go.
All right. I'm looking at the ANR
function on the Bloomberg terminal that
had tracks analyst recommendations. And
if you're not at health there 21 buys,
okay,
six holds and two sells. So, you know, I
think the streets still generally buying
off on this maybe this turnaround story,
but maybe they'll take a look at your
your story here today. Michelle Davis,
thank you so much for joining us. Uh
Michelle Davis is a senior deals
reporter for Bloomberg News joining us
live here in our Bloomberg Interactive
uh broker studio. Uh but it's
interesting to see on that on the
healthcare space. And again, I always
you come in here every Monday, Lisa, and
it's like there's an M&A deal coming out
of the healthcare space, which keeps the
likes of Michelle Davis busy on the deal
front. But it's again, we see it time
and time again in the healthcare space.
If you can't come up with that next drug
or that next, you know, procedure,
whatever in your R&D lab,
you got to join up.
You got to go buy somebody, you know,
you got to go go buy somebody. And
that's how the that business has played.
You're listening to the Bloomberg
Intelligence podcast. Catch us live
weekdays at 10 a.m. Eastern on Apple
CarPlay and Android Auto with the
Bloomberg Business App. Listen on demand
wherever you get your podcasts or watch
us live on YouTube.
All right, Lisa, Matteo, Paul Sweeney.
We're live here in our Bloomberg
Interactive Broker Studio streaming live
on YouTube. So check us out there. Um,
you know, to the extent I've had any
luck in meeting other people. It's been
at a bar and no dating apps here.
I know. I know. I met my husband at the
grease trucks at Ruckers after who
doesn't
having burgers. There you go.
Now, dating apps must evolve as Gen Z
redefineses romance. That's according to
a Bloomberg Intelligence survey. We're
going there, folks. We're going down
that rabbit hole. Nicole Duza joins us
here, internet and software equity
analyst for Bloomberg Intelligence.
Nicole, what's your survey? What are the
questions that asked and and what did
you find? Yeah. So, uh, we at Bloomberg
Intelligence conducted the survey to
better understand how people are
navigating dating, how they use dating
apps, and then also how they feel about
AI within dating apps. Uh, and so some
really interesting findings. First,
that, you know, specifically Gen Z tends
to be single but not dating.
Gen Z is what age again?
16 to 28. All right. So, I got
single.
Two of my four are into that one. Okay.
Go ahead. And so, they're not using the
apps.
They're not even dating. uh single and
not dating.
So this is
I mean there's a few reasons. Studies
have kind of shown they do have higher
rates of loneliness. Uh but they are
also prioritizing independence. They are
also uh you know feeling a reduced
stigma around being single. Uh so it
could really change dating patterns
generationally.
I can kind of say my son was on a dating
app and then he stopped because he got
tired of it and it just and he's in that
Gen Z kind of group. Um and they're not
going to pay for them too. So, how does
that change for these different, you
know, dating apps out there? How do they
have to change their approach?
So, right now, uh, a lot of what we're
seeing from Gen Z is that even though
they are dating less, they are looking
for long-term relationships. Those that
are dating, they are looking to form
meaningful connections. So, you know,
some of the products we've seen from
these dating apps that really introduce
AI are more around how to create a
profile, how to make it easier to talk
to people, you know, using AI to
generate prompts. That might not
necessarily, you know, correlate with
what Jenzie is looking for in terms of
forming a meaningful connection.
I'll tell you, Lisa, go to the Parker
House in Seagurt, New Jersey on a summer
Saturday,
New Jersey. Thousands and thousands of
kids of Gen Z type are there at like
4:00 in the afternoon. They're not on
the beach. They're all made up dressed
to the nines. I think they're looking to
hook to, you know, meet somebody.
I know. I've been there. I had to wait
on my dress.
So, I mean, I don't know what's going
on. How about millennials? How do they
fair?
So, millennials are they kind of came of
age during the time of dating apps. So a
lot of dating apps are really created to
target dating patterns of millennials.
So millennials have a more favorable
relationship with dating apps and they
also are much more
like comfortable with AI in dating apps
uh versus Gen Z which was surprising to
us.
Now what about Okay, people always
forget about Gen X. The Gen X folks.
What about Yeah. So what about Gen X?
And then you know my my mom you know
single like she wants to find out about
these apps. I'm telling you. What about
the older generation?
They're on dating apps. Um,
so they're on it.
There are Yeah, there are a lot of Gen X
and baby boomers on dating apps. And
there are a wide variety of dating apps
to kind of address different age groups,
different, you know, things that people
are looking for. So, they're they're
available.
How does AI have to ask the AI question
because because we had a guest on
earlier about I walked out of there
thinking AI is going to take over Wall
Street. How about AI and dating apps?
that I would think could be helpful to
better select somebody who might be a
good match or something.
So, we've seen dating app companies roll
out a lot of AI products. Um, I would
say right now it seems, at least based
on our survey, that they haven't been
that wellreceived. It seems like people
don't necessarily need AI to build a
better profile. They don't need AI to
help them engage in conversation. I
think where it has been helpful is user
safety. So to weed out profiles that are
fake or you know potentially send people
who are sending harmful messages. Um and
that is a common complaint but um as of
right now it doesn't seem that you know
at least Gen Z and even some millennials
are really really adopting these new AI
products.
So are there certain a dating apps that
are more popular than others? I mean
which are the hot ones right now?
So right now at least um by users Tinder
has by far the most users.
owned by Hinge is actually one of the
few dating apps that is continuing to
grow users. And that's probably because
Hinge focuses a little bit more kind of
long-term relationships, building
meaningful connections. Tinder still has
a reputation of kind of a hookup app.
Yes. Um
which one is that?
Tinder. Yeah, that's what my son was on.
A hookup app. Oh my god. And I mean, I'm
looking at uh uh Nicole's research
report. I mean, she's got graphs here of
like, I'm in a monogous relationship.
I'm single and currently dating. I'm in
an open relationship. Single but not
dating. In a casual relationship by demo
by baby boomers, Gen X millennials. I
mean,
who knew?
This is a lot of research here, dudes,
on dating. I mean, go to a bar, you
know, have a cocktail, relax. I don't
know. I don't know. It's good stuff
here. But Nicole, thanks so much for
joining us. Great research again at BI's
cutting edge research. Bloomberg
Intelligence uh using some survey data
here to go out and take a look at how
some of these um these apps are working
out there. Nicole Duza, she covers all
the uh internet stuff and all the uh
software stuff for Bloomberg
Intelligence.
You're listening to the Bloomberg
Intelligence podcast. Catch us live
weekdays at 10 a.m. Eastern
on Apple CarPlay and Android Auto with
the Bloomberg Business App. Listen on
demand wherever you get your podcasts or
watch us live on YouTube.
Black Rockck. Um, you know, the stock's
down, but I mean, it's Black Rockck. I
mean, 12 1.5 trillion in assets under
management. I can't get my mind around
that. Uh, it's just an extraordinary st
uh story. And by the way, it's separated
from Black Stone. I mean, imagine if
those two were together. Holy cow.
Anyway, I mean, it's got a market cap of
160 billion. Black Rockck is down 6%
today. Um up about 1% for the year. Uh
Neil Cypes is in studio. He's got to
explain to us what's going on there. He
covers all the asset managers for
Bloomberg Intelligence. Neil, talk to us
about Black Rockck Gear. They never seem
to have problems getting money in the
past. What's going on?
Yeah. Uh and I think what you're seeing
a little bit in the second quarter is
the net inflow figure was about half the
first quarter. Uh so perhaps a little
bit slower than than the analysts were
expecting. Uh but what I think is
encouraging and and sort of what we're
seeing with the transition, you even
mentioned Blackstone. Black Rockck is
trying to enter some of those businesses
in a more meaningful way that Blackstone
is involved in the private markets. We
saw the handful of transactions last
year, global infrastructure partners,
HPS. Uh and what this is going to do is
really sort of improve the organic base
fee growth. So, while we're seeing a
little bit slower on the net inflow
figure in terms of broader asset growth,
uh what it means is as we push further
into those private markets, those higher
fee products, uh that organic growth is
actually more meaningful to the
fundamentals of the business. So, we're
going to see a little bit of a
transition here. I think perhaps that's
what you're seeing uh in the second
quarter results today is that sort of
slower inflow growth uh but perhaps
still pretty robust base fee growth. And
let's not forget the second quarter was
uh really a tale of two stories. A
rather unique quarter with a very
challenging April and an incredible May
and June. So uh that is also sort of
balanced in the results. Um
now a lot of investors look to what the
executives are saying. So what kind of
tone did did CEO Larry Frink take?
Yeah, I I think he struck a generally
positive tone especially considering the
sort of broader macro uncertainties that
are still out there. It feels like we've
certainly moved back from some of the
the more worst case scenarios, we'll
call them, but there's still certainly
quite a bit of uncertainty, but when you
look at equity markets, uh you don't
necessarily see it, right? All-time
highs uh pretty much in the global
equities uh landscape. And so that's
generally a positive for asset managers,
particularly someone like Black Rockck.
And what they've talked about is they
experience momentum exiting the second
quarter and into the third quarter. Uh
clients continue to remain engaged. uh
they haven't necessarily pulled away in
sort of the volatility that we saw and
some of the uncertainty that we talk
about. Um so that sort of creates a
solid setup for Black Rockck moving
forward. All right. So for the asset
managers you like when I grew up in the
business the biggest customers on Wall
Street were the mutual funds and then
hedge funds became big.
Now it's ETFs.
How do the asset managers that you deal
with, you know, think about it? Just
seems like all the money is going to
ETFs.
How do your asset managers deal with
that?
Yeah. Uh well well there's the way you
deal with it is enter the ETF space to
sort of capture that flow. But that is a
business where scale is paramount
because you talk about ETFs, you're
thinking about average 10 basis point
fee rate, right? You're not going to
earn quite a bit. The margins are going
to be razor thin unless you're the size
of Black Rockck who garners 30% of the
market in US ETFs. That can be a
profitable business.
Yep.
Thought it was Vanguard.
And that's actually been shrinking from
over 40%. Vanguard's the one that's sort
of nipping at the heels, but again, it's
sort of an oligopoly with Vanguard,
Black Rockck, and Fidelity in the ETF
space, but how do you complement that in
a business where the flows are
increasingly going to ETFs? Well,
they're also going to private markets,
and that's why you saw again Black
Rockck push into that space last year.
All right, Neil, thanks so much. We
appreciate it. Uh Neil Cyps all the
banks and asset managers for Bloomberg
and Tons. This is the Bloomberg
Intelligence Podcast, available on
Apple, Spotify, and anywhere else you
get your podcasts. Listen live each
weekday, 10:00 a.m. to noon Eastern on
Bloomberg.com, the iHeart Radio app,
TuneIn, and the Bloomberg Business App.
You can also watch us live every weekday
on YouTube, and always on the Bloomberg
terminal.

cleanText:
Bloomberg Audio Studios, podcasts, radio, news.
You're listening to the Bloomberg Intelligence Podcast.
Catch us live weekdays at 10 a.m. Eastern on Apple CarPlay and Android Auto with the Bloomberg Business App.
Listen on demand wherever you get your podcasts or watch us live on YouTube.
Welcome back, Bloomberg Intelligence.
I'm Lisa Matteo alongside Paul Sweeney.
Big day for bank earnings.
Some mixed reports though.
Taking a look at the stock.
We have JPMorgan.
They're down, their shares down about half percent.
Wells Fargo down 5%.
We have Citigroup up about 1 and a.5%.
So here to break it all down for us and what happened with each bank is Alison Williams, Bloomberg Intelligence senior analyst, Global Banks and Asset Managers.
Alison, thanks for joining us here in the studio.
Good to see you.
Um, so let's start with JPMorgan, right?
They had some surprise deal making gains.
I mean, is that a sign that tariff fears are easing or how do you take it?
Yeah, I mean, they had a solid quarter.
There's always a high bar for JPMorgan, but I think a really good quarter, strong returns, uh, good organic growth, and I think, you know, about a billion dollars of upside with trading and fees.
And so, I think that we, you know, we did see that that fee pick up.
We saw April stall, then we saw fees really did pick up in in May and June.
As you said, it really is the advisory business was big upside um you know for both JPMorgan and Citigroup and um we also saw IPOs better and so we have seen that improving sentiment.
I think there is going to be a little bit of a lift in terms of some of the expectations for those banking fees going forward as well.
Red headline crossing the Bloomberg terminal.
Tesla's top North America sales executive Troy Jones exits.
That's according to the Wall Street Journal.
So when it rains, it pours there.
All right, here we go.
So we had JPMorgan, Citigroup, and Wells Report today.
Guess what?
I worked at all of those firms.
Chase Manhattan Bank, now part of JPMorgan.
Solomon Brothers, now part of Citigroup.
And Wheat First Securities, which is now part of Wells Fargo.
That's where Wells Fargo got its original broker dealer license by acquiring my firm, Weat Securities, Richmond, Virginia.
So I got I'm biased all over the place here.
Let's start with Citigroup.
I think that's got the most upside cuz I think it's underperformed for such a long time it was just begging for really really really good management.
Is this I mean the stock's hitting 52- week high today.
Is this the turnaround that everybody's been waiting for?
Do you think?
I think yeah Jane is getting it done right.
So, um, and and and to be fair, you know, her predecessors made some changes, but I think she's she's made some tough decisions, you know, especially the the sale of the, you know, the Mexico business where uh she really uh cut her teeth.
I think that is a a sign that she can be objective in terms of deciding what's right for the business and they are working their way up um to some better returns.
So, you know, we there's a lot of talk about the evaluation for Citigroup.
We know that they trade at a discount to their book value.
They trade at a discount to their peers.
Wow.
That's what happens when you don't um earn your cost of capital and your returns are below peers.
Yum but I think the changes that they're making are moving them in the right direction.
So when I look at Wells Fargo because I'm trying to go through the the information.
Um so the big thing that kind of stands out to me is that it crossed the 1.95 trillion asset mark.

um further a proposal out there that um you know there we're going to have sort of average results over time.

want to turn our attention to healthcare company uh managed care company UnitedHealth Group.

So yeah, as you mentioned, they had kind of a pristine record for more than 60 quarters.
They beat estimates.
Analysts love them.
And at the end of last year, that got a bit harder for them to keep up.
You know, medical costs were rising.
The government's been cracking down on on reimbursements, and that was eating into profits.
And so, what we reported is that at the end of last year, they approached several private equity firms and asked them if they wanted to buy stakes off of them of their businesses.
And a couple interesting things happened here.
Not only did they quietly do this, but the deals were structured such that United Health can be forced to buy the businesses back down the road.
So, it's temporary in nature.
And um United booked the gains in an interesting place.
They booked them as part of operating earnings, which is or adjusted earnings, which is normally where you look to see kind of how a business is doing, you know, excluding one-off gains or one-off events like this.
And so it was just interesting to see not only the fact that they stealthily did this but where they put them and and without these gains they would have missed estimates and profit would have dropped uh in the last quarter of last year.
So as I'm going through this article this this certain quote stands out for me from an analyst that you spoke to.
He said if the company is manufacturing earnings by chopping up their furniture or selling their assets that's not exactly a great business model.
Okay.
So, is the risk that it might be kind of masking this weakness in the operations?
That's the concern.

That's what we're trying to, you know, report on here.
But yeah, the the concern is it clouds, you know, your ability to see how the business is actually performing.
